history.content:
When a student is not a cs major, they will have the same enrollment priority for undergraduate cs classes as other students who are not cs majors.  

The class priority is in place to ensure students are able to graduate with the degree in a timely fashion -- a promise the department makes at least implicitly when you are accepted to the major -- without being displaced by other students to whom we have not such a promise or for whom such a promise has already been fulfilled.

We certainly hope we can accommodate everyone interested but we can't promise that.

Hey there,

Strongly considering doing a Master in Public Health @ Cal after I finish up double majoring here.

What's the policy in terms of enrolling and taking more CS upper divs in the two years after graduating undergrad? I'd love to continue taking data science classes and want to get around to taking some of the core CS classes that I'll probably miss out on but I think are still valuable to take (160, 162, 169, 170, maybeeeeee 189) after taking 100, 161, 168, 186, 188 here as an undergrad. 

Though I guess I technically won't be a CS major at that point can I... still maybe have CS major status + enrollment privileges, given my previous situation?
history.subject: Taking CS Classes as a graduate student
